Article.ArticleTitle: Fe-Mn doped powdered activated carbon pellet as ozone catalyst for cost-effective phenolic wastewater treatment: Mechanism studies and phenol by-products elimination.

AbstractText: A novel bimetallic doped PAC (Fe-Mn/PAC) pellet was prepared with a facile sol-gel method and used as an ozone catalyst for phenolic wastewater (PWW) treatment. Adoption of Fe-Mn/PAC pellet in microbubble ozonation enhanced the 1-h chemical oxygen demand (COD) and phenol removal in PWW to 79% and 95%, respectively. With ozone dosage of 10 mg/L, 1 g/L Fe-Mn/PAC pellet exhibited ozone conversion of 92%. In comparison to microbubble ozonation process, Fe-Mn/PAC induced microbubble-catalytic ozonation process promoted ozone decomposition rate by 1.9 times. In terms of <sup>•</sup>OH production, Fe-Mn/PAC pellet enhanced <sup>•</sup>OH exposure by 10 times, with a R<sub>ct</sub> value of 2.92 × 10 <sup>-8</sup>. R<sub>ct</sub> kinetic model also suggested that Fe-Mn/PAC pellet obtained higher kinetic rate constants for initiating and promoting <sup>•</sup>OH generation. Usage of Fe-Mn/PAC pellet in microbubble ozonation for phenolic wastewater treatment also reduced the total ozone consumption by 70%. In Fe-Mn/PAC induced microbubble-catalytic ozonation process, the ratio between ozone consumption and COD removal (ΔO<sub>3</sub>/ΔCOD) was 0.91. Fe-Mn/PAC pellet characterization with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) and X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) analysis revealed successful doping of Fe-Mn on PAC substrate and larger numbers of carbon-oxygen/hydroxyl surface groups, which played key roles in ozone decomposition and <sup>•</sup>OH production.
